Definition: In this task, ur given a public comment from onl platforms. Ur expected 2 classify da comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is defiend as anything that is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable that would make someone wan2 leave a converation.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I personally know and work with Muslims. None of them cover their faces.

Comment: I did read your post carefully and yes, you did have some positives in your comment.  

You suggested "offenders" need to be locked up during rehabilitation.  Why?  I am not saying everyone should be treated as an outpatient. I am saying that many should be in treatment centers opposed to incarceration centers.  Many would be inpatient.  Some should be in jail.

There are also differences between a drug addiction and alcohol addiction.  Different drivers. 

Unfortunately, your final sentence does state your position.  You imply victims do not win in Alaska and it is a joke to get a conviction in Alaska.  I think you are truly mistaken.  

In the ten years prior to SB 91, incarcerations in Alaska increased by 27%, three times the state population growth.  Two out of every three released were re-incarcerated within three years.  Three out of every four were incarcerated for non-violent crimes. 

We need to do a better job. We can do a better job.

Comment: I, too, have a dash-cam installed, front AND rear-facing.  It's already paid for itself from claims that something was my fault, when it wasn't. But without video proof, it becomes a he-said,she-said issue.  Insurance companies don't care.  Your own carrier simply charges you more, because YOU couldn't prove you're innocent.  I've even switched insurance carriers when they wouldn't agree my video evidence was enough.  Fortunately, the courts agreed with me.
An interesting outcome, is that I think I am driving more carefully WITH the dash-cam.  So it's a win-win for everyone.  Except the ones who get caught being stupid......

Comment: Yes, Doug Saunders  has been guilty in recent articles of equating those questioning neo-liberal globalism with anti-Semitism. However, in this article, I do believe he is drawing attention to the fact that the "left" movement of questioning neo-liberal globalism is to some degree being appropriated by anti Semitic groups. On those grounds, I agree.

After all, we now are faced with much on-line commentary that suggests neo-liberal globalism is the product of the "left". When young leftists were drawing the WTO agenda to a halt in Seattle 1999, they were being called out as fringe and communists by those on the "right". So many of those who cheered regional trade agreements and investor dispute mechanisms have changed their minds........and now suggest it was the "left". 

Yet, I do believe Doug Saunders might want to clear the air with a column in which he makes it clear not all those questioning neo-liberal globalism are anti-Semitic etc - unless he wants to create the false image.

The Club can answer questions at a press conference, but apparently not in a comment thread like this.  Go figure!  But what I can do is tell you why I personally believe environmentalists should support Kirk Caldwell’s re-election.
The biggest environmental concern on the planet -the biggest single security and political priority bar none- is climate change.  The current prognosis is terrifying.  Our rainfall patterns on O‘ahu are already changing appreciably, rainfall is diminishing and our freshwater aquifers are not being recharged as fast as needed.  Seas around O‘ahu will be a foot higher than today in 30 years and could be more than 6 feet higher by the turn of the century according to the School of Ocean and Earth Science and Technology at UH. Comment: Pilot, re "Trump’s strategy to get free media," thanks for that, you made me think. And if that's true, shouldn't we worry that it's working? So I would have expected statements like those that JP cites would have had the voters, and the media, dismiss him as not smart enough or well-spoken enough to be a candidate. Comment: http://www.tax.alaska.gov/programs/programs/index.aspx?60650
The State of Alaska imposes a production tax, under AS 43.55, on oil and gas produced in the state. The current tax rate of 35% was set in 2013 by Senate Bill 21 (commonly known as the More Alaska Production Act or “MAPA”). The tax is based on the net value of oil and gas, which is the value at the point of production, less all qualified lease expenditures. Qualified lease expenditures include certain qualified capital and operating expenditures. 
Senate Bill 236, House Bill 280, and Senate Bill 309 signed in 2010, by Governor Sean Parnell, created new tax credits and amended some provisions of the tax. 
Parnell's and Republican gifts to big oil.

Comment: This issue, in a nutshell, explains the conceit of the Liberal's claim that they make decisions based on "evidence based reasoning."

In the modern, real world, issues are complicated, and decision making is based upon competing interests, values, and (yes) various predictions based on existing evidence.

Here, you have an issue on what blood alcohol limit is the cutoff limit (legally, you can be impaired without being over 08).  Any limit, by its nature, is in a sense arbitrary.

While it is a valuable debate, and the 08 limit isn't sacrosanct, I believe it should be kept.  For the reasons mentioned in the article, and because most drunk driving accidents feature drivers way above the 08 limit.

More concerning, for a "rights" party, the Liberals seem to be intent on stepping on them.  No "reasonable suspicion" for a breath sample.  Far worse, the Liberals legislation to cripple the accused defense in a sexual assault trial.

And yet, Wilson thinks mandatory minimums violate rights.

Comment: This is not speculation or propaganda, though. The information security community knows, not  everything, but a lot about the computer network exploitation capabilities of most large nation states. China, like the US, runs this as a military capability, but their teams are a lot more decentralized than American hackers. Russia is quite different altogether. We know the general methodologies that each prefers (which often reflect the organizational structure), the kinds of tools each prefers, and we know the types of targets they go after.

People who study this have access not only to forensic analysis of breaches, but also get a lot of data from accidental leaks, and often the attackers' servers are compromised, with contents then publicized. US and Cdn intel services know even more than is public, because they directly attack Russian and Chinese hacker groups.

You can choose not to believe it, but that is not something you can reconcile with objective facts.

Comment: This column reeks of anti-Conservative bias.  I attended an all-candidates debate yesterday in BC and I heard only one candidate talk, in rather mild terms, about changing our immigration policies.  Three candidates argued forcefully against this.  On the whole, the level of debate was very high, and I found it quite inspiring.

The trouble with the Liberal motion is that it sets the stage for shutting down legitimate speech in Parliament and elsewhere.  Of course it carries no legal weight, but we don't want parliament signalling that it is inherently bigoted to be skeptical about  refugees and the potential of large-scale immigration from various countries. Canada needs immigrants, but it is perfectly reasonable to want immigrants to integrate to our way of life, as earlier generations of immigrants have all done.  Some will tell you that this will happen of its own accord, but a great many are beginning to doubt this and should feel free to express their concerns.

Comment: So you think there wasn't a single rational justification for the age-old, virtually UNIVERSAL definition of marriage as one man, one woman?  What hubris.

Your citation of Article 10 of the Declaration of Human Rights does nothing to support you cause.  The right to marry is FUNDAMENTAL in the United States as well, and yet it woud have been though laughable, until recently, to say that this fundamental right to marry included the right to marry someone of the same sex.  Why?  Because "marriage," by definition, meant one man, one woman (although in some instances, polygamy), but never man-man or woman-woman.    Note, by the way, that the Declaration, Article 10, says "without any limitation due to race, nationality or religion."  It does not forbid a prohibition on grounds of sex, meaning man marrying man or woman marrying woman.  Indeed, such a prohibition would have been though absurd when the Declaration was passed in 1948, because the very idea of such "marriage" was absurd.

Comment: My wife retired as a full-time nursing professor a couple of years ago and her position is now being staffed by several part-timers.  The nursing program has been running since the colleges took them over in the 60's and has no signs of slowing down.  How is this reacting to market forces?  They need experienced full-time staff for the majority of the program delivery and continuity to ensure quality.

The reality is that instead these colleges have loaded up management administrators at the expense of front-line teaching staff.  The number of these managers has DOUBLED over the past 16 years while the number of faculty members has decreased relative to the number of students in the same period.  I estimate that the college system could save $200 million annually just by going back to the 2001 ratio of management to students.

What other organizations have doubled their management staff ratio?  It's ridiculous.

Comment: Would we like to see a pipeline/LNG facility? Well sure - I'd venture to say most would agree that it would be a great thing IF it penciled out. 
But that's just it. It doesn't pencil out. If the state ends up building it (it won't happen anyway), it would likely cost twice as much to finance and operate the complex and pay the producers than what it would bring in revenue. That's what we call harvesting Alaska's resources NOT to the maximum benefit of the people, but rather the maximum detriment to the people. 
Now take the TAPS pipeline on the other hand couldn't be built fast enough by eight world class oil companies and not a single dime of public money spent to build it. And now 40 years of no taxes, PFD's, infrastructure improvements and a $60 billion nest egg later, the oil and TAPS operation has been a maximum benefit to Alaska as required by the constitution. 
Unfortunately it's not looking the same way with natural gas.

Comment: I'm glad you agree on the first part.  I'm still concerned about the second part.  In the context of his key 30-35 minute speech explaining his views fully to the public, I think a statement similar to what I wrote above has to be written, because otherwise you are not capturing the minutes of the meeting.   You are leaving out things because you've heard them before.  By that criteria, there would be nearly nothing to report from Washington because we hear the same things over and over.  But the reason we hear things over and over is because they were key aspects of whatever unfolded on that particular day at that particular time.  Each day must be a day to its own. The rules of reporting can never be changed.  It must report the event. It can add more context, but it can't leave out key aspects, no matter what.  That's all I can say, I guess. Thanks for the dialog. You've been generous. Thank you.

Comment: If you need more $ for infrastructure, cut waste across the fed. gov.!  But as to the math... Against that there is the fact they expect to make a decent return, much more than the % cost of debt to the government. Comment: I taught high school math a long time ago, having graduated with major in math. I love math and enjoyed teaching it, having tutored all through university. I had some academic classes which were a joy to teach. I also had "general course" non-academic, baby-sitting classes i was told  No baby-sitter, I,  thought they should learn some math and very quickly discovered that they didn't know simple arithmetic. I taught the addition and multiplication tables and did some rote learning. We also did consumer finance: compound interest, mortgages, furniture store "pay later!" add-on interest. The school I taught in had math teachers with math background.  Later I had a great time substituting for some Grade 12 classes. The lesson I was supposed to give they all groaned and said already did. So, I entertained them with geodesics. Geometry of the sphere.  Oooh parallel lines meet at the poles! Comment: continued……
.
As for arsenic, it appears that "measurable levels" is your threshold for safety.  So, your acceptable level of arsenic  depends on your definition of "measurable levels".  "Measurable" by what means?  In order to obtain measurable amounts of arsenic, or any other contaminant in water fluoridated with HFA, takes 10 times the manufacturer’s maximum use level.   In stringent NSF Standard 60 testing of water fluoridated with the proper use level of HFA, there is no measurable arsenic. 
.
“In fact, NSF was only able to detect the reported trace amounts by dosing the chemicals into water at ten times the manufacturers maximum use level (as required by the Standard). If the products had been dosed into water at the manufacturer’s maximum use level, all contaminant levels would have been below the analytical method detection limits.” 
.
—Fact Sheet on Fluoridation Substances
NSF International
.

to be continued….
.
Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: If you have an open comment section it should not block any statements or people UNLESS they violate some pre-set "hate" or "language" standards. Otherwise, yes, the comments should be open for free speech. And I agree that free speech comes with consequences--ie., a football player sitting during the national anthem has to deal with the consequences (if any) from fans, or a Yale professor posting racist rants on Yelp reviews should (and did) get terminated. Free speech does and should have consequences. But, as long as the rules are the same for everyone on a public comment board, and those rules have not been violated, then all comments should be welcome and published.

Comment: Protests aren't necessarily hate. That's just bizarre. Protesting is a constitutional right (you know, that first amendment?). And protesting is not the same thing as destroying property. Sure, people have a right to their feelings - but you have to admit that there's a problem when somebody's hate revolves around efforts to deny equal standing to others whom he/she sees as fundamentally lesser, such as neo-Nazis or white supremacists. Personally, I don't think such hate should be criminalized, but it absolutely should be excoriated, loud and clear. Because that's not the America I want to live in. 

Finally, though violence is always wrong, in terms of message there is no comparison between antifa and white supremacists. Anita is against fascism - ethnic cleansing, blood and soil, etc. White supremacists and neo-Nazis are by definition hateful and exclusionary. They're not even remotely comparable.

Comment: "...supporting a large shelter downtown that is easily accessible to homeless people."

How big a shelter might this be, where in downtown might it be located, and how would it help to revitalize and make our downtown safer?

Downtown and residential neighborhoods are not the right locations for publicly funded permanent shelters. Those of us who pay property taxes already directly and indirectly support a wide variety of services and places (like the library) that serve and shelter homeless people. Most of us don't want our homes, neighborhoods, or downtown further impacted and devalued by tax funded permanent shelters... especially "low barrier". Whiteaker is a an example of what can happen with increased and concentrated homeless populations.

There are publicly owned lands that can better handle more shelters (if need truly be) further out and even served by taxpayer funded buses.

Yes, if Eugene continues to be expanded as a homeless Mecca, more will come. They already have...

Comment: With all afforded respect to these members of the community, however they never really answer, in any detail, some of the more germane questions that remain.

One, that any action via the international route, would ironically still require not just the explicit consent of the US, it would additionally require its allies on the security council to also approve. These are highly pragmatically decisions that have at its inflection points, decisions that would fissure long-standing diplomatic relationships. The fact that the US is a permanent member of the UN Security Council, and the only grouping globally that can promulgate binding resolutions, severely limits current options and paths.

Two, is the identification of an appropriate judicial body and/or tribunal that would consider to hear the case--the fact of the matter is there is none.

Finally, nothing about the path proposed by DOI would preclude an international route down the road. These are the facts of the matter...

Comment: Thanks for your response GL, but I have to take issue with it.

There's solid evidence that there were more extreme storms occurring not only before the industrial revolution and the widespread usage of fossil fuels, but even before man walked the planet-
http://events.nytimes.com/2002/10/25/science/25FLOO.html?mcubz=0
https://www.uvm.edu/cosmolab/people/noren/noren_ms_thesis.pdf

And more recent records of tropical storms and hurricanes >100 yrs show their levels fluctuating similarly before and after the industrial revolution-
https://www.gfdl.noaa.gov/historical-atlantic-hurricane-and-tropical-storm-records/

Finally, data shows that Hurricane Harvey developed in an environment in which atmospheric and ocean temperatures were near normal, and slightly above normal in the Gulf, and any climate change effect would have resulted in only an extra inch of rain-
http://cliffmass.blogspot.com/2017/08/global-warming-and-hurricane-harvey.html?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter

Comment: If you read my comment again you'll see that I was suggesting that raising the Second Amendment to equal status with the Ten Commandments was a form of idolatry, not the Second Amendment itself.

I'd like to point out that no less a champion of the Second Amendment than Antonin Scalia went out of his way to state that Second Amendment rights are not unlimited. He said that many laws limiting those rights are still valid and enforceable, such as: guns in the hands of mentally ill, guns in sensitive places like schools and government buildings, regulations on the sale of arms, and other necessary laws that may restrict the right to carry weapons. He wrote the majority opinion in the Heller case.

Also, in my opinion it is the gun and ammunition industry that is behind the drive against any and all efforts to bring down the level of gun violence, as it affects their bottom line--money. I have no doubt that most NRA members decry the carnage we're witnessing.

Comment: "the electricity we use is generated largely at co-generation stations which burn natural gas"

https://www.bchydro.com/energy-in-bc/our_system/generation/our_facilities.html

"92% of BC Hydro's power generation is hydroelectric", oh, so that is why they call it BC Hydro. -)

BC Hydro Burrard Thermal 960 MW Generating station is a standby unit, only used when there is a disruption in power transmission, or in low flow years when the hydro reservoirs run low on water. Firing it up during the made in Enron crisis was an exception to the normal cooled off but ready to warm up status.

The 46 MW Prince Rupert and 73 MW Fort Nelson thermal generating facilities are penny ante, compared to the 31 Hydroelectric generation stations.

Comment: You don't appear to be a very apt biologist, but rather a nasty troll spreading ill informed false moral equivalency.  Comparing a few thousand annual dropout sockeye salmon in directed fisheries in Bristol Bay to a large scale mechanized mining operation is just plain stupid.  These mining operations have a terrible track record in Canada, Eastern Europe, China, South America, and New Guinea.  The potential for irrevocable harm to the habitat is very real.  Dead sockeye salmon resulting from gilnetting that go unharvested will contribute to the nutrient cycle.  Moreover it is has been going on since the inception of the most productive commercial wild salmon fishery on earth for nearly 140 years and has not done harm to the sustainability of the run.  Damaging habitat however is the most widespread cause of extirpation of fish stocks.

Comment: The Orthodox have a different take on re-union. In his book, ORTHODOXY, Timothy Ware notes:  "Orthodoxy recognizes that, in the early centuries of the Church, Rome was pre-eminent in its steadfast witness to the true faith; but we do not believe that, in his teaching ministry, the Pope possesses a special charisma or gift of grace that is not granted to his fellow bishops. We recognize him as first -- but only as first among equals. He is the elder brother, not supreme ruler. We do not consider that, in the first ten centuries of the Church, the Pope possessed direct and immediate power of jurisdiction in the Christian east, and so we find it impossible to grant such power to him today." They wish to see the Pope's ministry and honorary seniority spelled out in pastoral terms, not juridical terms.

Comment: Yes there are cameras at the gates, they installed them just last winter. (I live nearby and fish there almost every day). But there's nothing to indicate it was a boater, they said the shooter fled on foot. It happened near the west boat ramp, but there is a swim beach, marina, restaurant, big parking lot, and group picnic area, all adjacent to the ramp. It's a busy area. It could have been anyone. There is also a boat inspection station at the top of the ramp, which was manned by a ranger at the time. I was there shortly before the shooting but I saw nothing unusual. A storm had come through earlier and it wasn't as crowded as it normally is. I would like to hear the details though as I spend a lot of time fishing there, often after dark. Quite a few others do too. I don't understand how someone who shot someone isn't a threat to the community so I'd like to hear more details as well, hopefully forthcoming soon. I think I'll skip fishing tonight though.

Comment: Obamacare was a mistake.  The Democrats had the votes to get a single-payer medical system.  

Our health care system is run on a horrible model.  It essentially exists as a tax on all the major employers.  All major employers have to offer health insurance to compete with other companies in getting employees.  This is a huge drag on our businesses, especially the small businesses that do not have enough employees to create a cheaper pool for insurance.  It also severely hampers self-employed people that cannot take advantage of the big businesses large numbers of employees in the insurance pool.  The current system also results in people staying employed longer to get the medical benefits - the walking retired.  I do not understand why the Chamber of Commerce is not for a single-payer medical system and to remove these restrictions on our economy.

Comment: I'm not certain (as I'm certainly no American history scholar nor a Church history scholar), but I've never been under the delusion that the American church has a sterling record on racism encompassing the past couple of hundred years.  Was the RCC noted, as are the Quakers, for its rigorous anti-slavery actions and words?  Were all of our parishes desegregated before the Civil Rights act?  Did we have strong, outspoken Southern bishops who mandated equality that countered cultural norms prior to the 1960's?  I'm hoping there are a few standout examples of genuinely anti-racist bishops and parishes, but I've never read or been otherwise informed that the RCC has been staunchly active toward human rights in this particular matter.  I may be absolutely wrong and would welcome being corrected on this impression.  My point is, we don't have (as far as I know) a proud history in this critical matter and it's past time to begin to heal both the present and the past.

Comment: Dear Rule and Raven,
I believe most Catholics, lay and cleric, assume that a properly formed conscience is always in harmony with the teaching of the magisterium and, therefore, a man in a same sex marriage is living in a state of sin.  I question the assumption.  For one thing, I believe the entire cosmos is theophany and that the sciences can tell us as much about the will of God as can Scripture.  What we read in the Bible is an account of how people have interpreted revelation and that interpretation is conditioned by what they already believed as taught and understood in their own cultures.  As our scientific understanding of humanity deepens through science, I believe we have to accept that past understandings do not represent the "Will of God" as much as the understanding (or misunderstanding) of humans.  It is high time to review the magisterium's  understanding in light of modern science as well as developments in the study of Scripture.

Comment: Nobody is saying they should make "everything" part of the job. That's just overblown straw man rhetoric.

The NFL is an entertainment business. They sell 3+ hour events to the public. The main event is the game itself, but if you've ever been to a game or seen one on TV, you know there's more to the event than the game alone. There's pregame activities and post-game activities as well. PUBLIC activities, that are part of the event that the employees are there putting on for the public. One of the pieces of the whole event is a performance of the national anthem, on the field, usually on TV, where the cameras put the players, coaches, staff, etc on display standing and showing respect for the national anthem.

You could complain about not liking that the national anthem is part of the pregame, but the fact is that IT IS. And like any employees, NFL employees are expected to partake in that ceremony as PART OF THE JOB. Perfectly legal for them to make it a job requirement.

Comment: I believe that homelessness is an issue that needs to be addressed, but there is a big difference between the "homeless" and "Travelers".  "Homeless" to me means that a person is in need and wants to do better for themselves and family. The true "homeless" are the people who try to better their situation by taking ownership and putting in effort. Because you see someone on the corner does not mean they are "homeless", it's just their choice to get money. It is a fact that some "homeless" do not what to better themselves, that is on them, not me for take care of. 

"Travelers" to me are people that are "traveling" and have stopped to get what they can before traveling on. Many travelers are young and are part of the "gimmie" generation and do not care of the community they are in, or the people that live here. They just get all then can and then leave to get more from somewhere else.

So, let break from lumping the "homeless" and "Travelers" together, they are not one and the same.

Comment: From http://www.fee.org/the_freeman/detail/the-flat-tax-simplicity-desimplified

    We owe to Robert Heinlein the memorable if nearly unpronounceable TANSTAAFL (there ain’t no such thing as a free lunch), which expresses one of the most fundamental principles in all of economics. Each major field of study within economics would do well to find its own Heinleinian acronym so as to keep policy prescription anchored to the basics. Let me propose a suitable one for the field of public finance: TANSTAABST. There ain’t no such thing as a big simple tax. Head taxes, the only truly simple taxes, are never big; income taxes, the primary source of revenue for the welfare state, are never simple. The claim, made repeatedly by supply-siders, that with a flat tax our tax form would be the size of a postcard can easily be exposed as bad science fiction.

The character limitation does not allow me to quote more from this, but the author does explain just why a flat tax would not, in fact, be simple.

Comment: Foreigners also buy multiple properties or converting basements for rental to collect rent for retirement. That by itself isn't really a problem, because the home still ends up in the rental market for Canadians. There are a number of sides to this problem and only a few tangible solutions.

(1) Homes sometimes get bought by speculators and not rented out. This is the easy one, tax vacant homes and potentially tax home flipping, i.e. homes that you don't keep for, say, 3 years at least.

(2) Foreigners cumulatively have a lot of capital to spend, and want to spend it in Canada for a number of reasons. This is not a long-term problem if they intend to live, work and get taxed here, but it causes more competition so incumbents hate it. No easy solution except discrimination by country of origin.

(3) Both Canadians and Chinese love low-rise single-family housing near city centres, and are willing to pay up for it. Unsustainable, no easy solution, attitudes will have to change over time.

Comment: I encourage everyone to take a detailed look at Shishmaref on Google Maps.  Shishmaref is built on a tiny barrier island with a tidal basin behind it. But waves and currents will do what they want with the island;  shoring up one area will just encourage erosion in another.  I'd say to stay put and move the buildings when threatened.

Comment: I enjoy reading the front page of the National Enquirer and the Globe as I wait in line at the drug store.

Every issue has at least one cover story headline that is hilarious.  Laughter is the best medicine, even at the drug store.

As well, it frequently leads to a lively and interesting conversation with the person behind me in the line.  

One of my favourites was about Bob Hope after he turned 90.  Once a year every year, the Enquirer would run a story with the front page heading "Bob Hope On Death Bed".  

Finally, when he turned 101, they were right.

If the Enquirer cared about Canadian political stories, they could always run one every year under the headline "Trudeau Liberals Balance The Budget".  By 2055, they might be right.

More seriously, I have found that common sense, historical knowledge, a critical eye, checking coverage of the same story from opposite sources (e.g. Fox and MSNBC) and following the money and the power are enough to separate real from fake news.

Comment: This is excellent. Really! 

I regard the First Nations of Canada as our National Treasure.  When I first read the writings of Archibald Belaney known to history as Grey Owl, I wanted to be an Indian.  My parents were not prejudiced against anyone. They taught that racism is a false god.  When I was in my late twenties, I had the chance to live for a year on the Six Nations of the Grand River.  Because I respected the people, I was treated accordingly. One night while on the way to a dance off the Reserve, I asked the driver if only Indians would be there. He replied, "You're an Indian, sort of."  Nice!

Canada's treatment of the First Nations sanctioned by the government under the aegis of Christian clergy unleashed a legacy of racial terror upon children of the First Nations.  Only when Canadians en mass come to terms with this blight upon our historical pass, will Canada attain its high destiny.  Drew Hayden Taylor's article is a reminder how far we have to go.  

All my relations

Comment: I don't think that justification makes any sense because, more often than not, ALL investments just get transferred to another investment but capital gains are still charged on them.

How is, for example, selling stocks in Company A and using the proceeds to buy stocks in Company B any different, in this regard, then selling one house to buy another?  The first is charged capital gains, the second is not.

As for the tax changes, they would be complicated because if you are treating a primary residence like any other investment then you can start deducting interest expenses and maintenance expenses, just like what you can do with a rental property.  It isn't any insurmountable level of complexity by any means (as noted above the rules already exist for rental properties, recreational properties, etc.), but it would make things more complicated.

Comment: "The proposed changes would grant the president powers to appoint ministers, senior government officials and half the members of Turkey’s highest judicial body, as well as issue decrees and declare states of emergency. It sets a limit of two five-year terms for presidents and also allows the president to remain at the helm of a political party."

Hmmm... seems to me that the Prime Minister of Canada already has all of these powers.  The Canadian PM appoints the cabinet; the PM controls the appointments of senior Deputy Ministers; and the PM can appoint all of the members of the Supreme Court and of the Superior courts in each province (not just half of them, as in Turkey).  And the PM can declare states of emergencies (e.g., 1970 October Crisis) and sets policies. In Turkey, the leader will be limited to two five-year terms whereas in Canada, a PM can serve longer.  So unless I hear of more specific powers granted by these amendments, I will keep an open mind.

Comment: This editorial misses the point in two ways.  First, covering the female face is not a basic tenet of Islam, it is a cultural practice of extreme variants of the religion. This makes it very different from the Sikh turban, and different even from the Jewish kippah.  The latter is not worn by most Jews, but all Jews recognize that an observant Jew must wear it. Observant Muslim women are not in general expected to wear the niqab.

The second issue is the rationale for the legislation in Quebec and many European countries. It has little to do with security and nothing to do with discrimination.  It is simply a fact that, in our culture, and most others, human interchange can only proceed successfully on a face to face basis.  This applies to business, education, and many services. It doesn't apply to riding on a bus or walking around on the street. The law should be amended, but its basis is sound.

Comment: The real weakness in the Charter/constitutional argument as well as the cost argument put forward by the pro-settlement faction is that the Khadr settlement does absolutely nothing to enhance or protect the Charter rights of Canadians nor does it provide any value for funds spent. Definitionally, settlements do not establish legal precedents upon which others can rely in the future to establish claims or seek damages. The Khadr case raised several important issues, including the extent to which national security can be held to justify Charter infringements as well as whether the actions of a claimant can be held to mitigate damages relating to Charter violations. Now we'll never know, at least unless or until another such case emerges. So, we paid Khadr's settlement money as well as the legal costs already incurred to establish essentially nothing. My view is that spending another $20 or $30 million to fully litigate the case would have been worth the clarity that would have emerged.

I certainly "sold early" however I avoided the collapse and can actually say that I made money on Nortel.

While stocks such as BMO should be fine as a long term hold, stocks such Valeant and Blackberry outline the fact that by selling early, you may miss out on some tremendous gains, however you will avoid being wiped out as well.

Surprisingly, it appears that the repair is not necessarily that expensive.  In 1994, depending on the spec, the manual transmission would be an LT77 or R380 (it's a transitional year), and rebuilt versions with upgraded components are only £595-£1595 from some of the LR specialists such as Ashcroft Transmissions.

Given that an early 1990s LHD Defender still commands $25-$50K, it may be a worthwhile repair (along with a fresh clutch, throwout bearing and rear main seal).

The LT77 is known for weak 2nd & 3rd gear synchros...

Look around you. Think about the last time you used that old exercise equipment or that third TV. And never mind all the rubbish in your junk drawer. Why keep it all?

Comment: "That became the "Stranded debt" and the Debt Retirement charge was meant to cover some of this."
============

There was, of course, one big problem with this plan:  Mike Harris' PCs failed to fully limit the definition of "stranded debt".

... then along came Dalton McGuinty.

McGuinty saw the lack of transparency and limitation of "stranded debt" as an opportunity.  During his tenure he moved all kinds of general government debt onto the "standard debt" books.  In 2003/04, under McGuinty, the "residual stranded debt" jumped from $7.7B up to $11.5B.  Why?  No one really knows.  The Auditor General of Ontario looked into this a little while back and basically called the government out on being dishonest, but nothing much came from it.  Here is the report:

http://www.auditor.on.ca/en/content/annualreports/arreports/en13/404en13.pdf

Comment: Dave ignores it, but as much of Doug Porter’s note dealt with the out-of-control Toronto housing market as the strong January GDP numbers. If one looks at housing inflation rates in Canada as compared to the US, the nonchalance of the Bank of Canada borders on the criminally irresponsible. The Teranet National Bank HPI showed a 13.4% inflation rate for March, up from 13.0% in February, as opposed to a 5.9% inflation rate for the US Case-Shiller national HPI for January with a 6.0% backcast for February. Yet the Bank of Canada made no mention of the out-of-control increases in housing prices in its January MPR as a risk to the inflation outlook.

Comment: I try to stay out of everyone's way, but even at 70 mph, the "Fast-packs" are on me so quickly that they can pinch me between them and slower traffic.  On some of the two-lane each way, divided highway, merging traffic is especially dangerous, because the merging vehicle under-estimates the speed of the packs.  The packs pass on my right, and pull in front of me almost scraping bumpers, while weaving back and forth between lanes.  The slower lane is often following too close for me to fit in between them.  And some of the slow traffic is so slow, that there is no safe way to merge with them, from 70 to 45, while some "road-rage" clown is pressing my rear bumper , at 20 feet or less.   I strive always for as much distance, front and rear, between me and the packs.  You see that lone vehicle "way ahead, or way behind there"?  That's me!  I'm happy to note though, that almost all of the 18 wheelers stay very close to the posted 65mph.  At least I don't have to contend with them also.

Comment: Auditors say that many such cases of ongoing, systematic fraud or embezzlement start with a small incident that may not even have criminal intent. For example, maybe she sent a personal UPS shipment or bought some gas for her personal vehicle on the company card and intended to reimburse SL. Then she forgot about it and realized they had, too. 

Next, small thefts (by now she probably realized she wouldn't repay them, although perhaps she rationalized that she still intended to) became a pattern, and as each one went undiscovered, she became more bold and also better able to rationalize them ("nobody seems to even notice!").  Once it is an established habit, the person steals freely up to the limits of their opportunity.

This, of course, is why it is necessary to have oversight in place to identify and address the small problems before they become big ones.

Comment: How silly. Subsidizing health care and not subsidizing all the other aspects of life for the poor. We have done the same thing. Both the US and Canada provide housing for the poor, and in general it seems more like a ghetto. Then there are bus passes. And no doubt other items to be supported. 

Just think if we were or became poor, would we want that type of treatment. Or would we want a Guaranteed Annual Income so we can have some control over our living? In the US it would mean that the poor could choose the level of health care which they would want. Not one size fits all if only health care were subsidized. 

So the US has an excellent opportunity. Remove all legislation regarding health care. Pay the poor a Guaranteed Annual Income (the poor and only the poor). Then the poor can decide how to live their lives, where they can live within their means, what level of health care they want. Better food or a beer. 

Not a specified health care package. Their selection.

Comment: Houston is a special case in that Houston's highways were specifically designed to drain flood waters from the low-lying and flat Houston metropolis. Putting millions of motorists into traffic jams on those flooded highways just before the storm appeared with little warning time would have caused many, many more deaths. This is just what happened when hurricane Rita hit Houston and more people died in Rita than Harvey, although Harvey dropped much more rain.
While the population of the Keys is a tiny fraction of Houston's and storm surge could completely sweep over many islands in the Keys, leaving no option to shelter in place as millions did successfully in Houston during Harvey.
There is no one-size-fits-all solution, there is no replacement for advance planning with site-specific knowledge.

Comment: " grapes at King Estate in Eugene"
Nice vineyard photos.  However, King Estate is NOT in Eugene.
It is at the south end of  historic Territorial Highway, high on  a ridge over the Upper Siuslaw Valley, just north of the village of Lorane.
It's time the RG understands the north-south string of fine wineries along Territorial Hwy  from Monroe in the north to Chateau Lorane in the south.  This is the result of the favorable  natural terroir along the foothills of the Coast Range and the valleys  of the Long Tom River, Coyote Creek and the Siuslaw River.  
Not only are these fine wineries, you are following the ancient HBC Trappers Trail/California Trail through some beautiful natural scenery and by some venerable farms.

Comment: [People should not vote if they are not an informed voter.]
I have to disagree with you.  First off, who is an objective enough judge to determine what is or is not an "informed" vote?  Secondly, the democratic system we rely on functions best when everyone participates not just the 20% or so that turns out for the local/primary elections.  Next, a good portion of those are merely voting based upon party rather than information.  By your suggestion we'd see maybe 2-5% of voters turning out.  Also, uninformed voters, statically speaking, should be a wash so they aren't likely to be a deciding factor anyway.  Finally, I just simply have to disagree with you a more fundamental level.  Any vote is a good vote so long as it is cast in good faith.  While it is preferable to cast an informed vote the fact that one's information is limited or the voter is apathetic in most political matters doesn't make his/her participation any less valued or any more unwanted.

Comment: A strong case exists that no one during the Brexit Referendum campaign argued for a hard Brexit and that the narrow outcome of that vote is no legal or democratic barrier to demands that UK-EU negotiations focus upon reform to the EU rather than Brexit itself.  The shambles that marks the UK political scene, however, makes it highly unlikely that the zombie-like progress of the Conservative Government (itself deeply divided over all aspects of Brexit) towards a hard Brexit will end. 

The Labour Party implosion and the peripheral standing of the SNP, Ulster Parties and the Liberal Democrats on the UK wide scene make it highly improbable that an effective coalition campaign against pursuing a hard Brexit can be mounted.

In particular, Tony Blair is not the catalyst to rally Conservative, Labour, SNP and Ulster opponents to form such a coalition.

Comment: Well, as a veteran I am grateful for being able to use the VA system. Great people. 
But, the best medical program I have experienced was the original Oregon Health Plan set up by Governor Kitzhaber. For low income Oregonians it allowed me to quickly see a doctor just two blocks away, with no deductible, and it also included basic dental and vision. It was simple and I suspect was fairly inexpensive. It's implementation was efficient and flexible. 
If given the choice between that Oregon Health Plan and the VA system, or medicare, I would choose that Oregon Health Plan. Most vets don't get dental care. While there is a limited dental plan for veterans, it is quite limited.
Even if national health care is expensive, it is probably the most important thing our govenment can do, get decent medical care to all Americans. I do worry about the future of the Affordable Care Act, and by the way, it is not permitted for veterans to enroll in both the VA and that system.
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: R2P is for situations when a largely defenceless group- typically a minority- are turned on by their own government. The Syrian conflict never justified a response under R2P. That's first because the rebellious group are the majority in Syria. And second because from the earliest days of the conflict, foreign powers were arming, training and financing the rebels. (Simply put, you can't stoke the flames of a conflict and then justify your intervention under R2P.)

Of itself, a deadly crisis within a country doesn't justify an intervention under R2P. This is true even if the crisis is a long-lasting armed rebellion. R2P is only justified when a government commits- OR PERMITS- the gravest of crimes against its people on a massive scale.

In Myanmar today, one of the worst crimes is happening: ethnic cleansing. It's happening on a massive scale: 400,000 people so far. The Responsibility to Protect principle, R2P, was created for exactly this sort of calamity. Don't let it go to waste.

Comment: The problem with Feldman's quote is that it's meaningless from a public policy perspective, and as a lobbyist he knows it. When you are trying to achieve a goal you have access to multiple levers. A good person with a gun will not cause harm. A bad person with a less effective weapon is limited in the damage they can cause. A bad person with the best weapon but no one to use it on cannot cause harm. So if your goal is to reduce harm you can try to craft any of those situations.

The problem with 'looking at the type of person' is that there are 323 million people in the US. For absolutely anything illegal (e.g. drugs) you can find a large minority of people who could handle it responsibly. The statement '[Blank] doesn't [blank], people [blank].' applies to absolutely everything. But in all other things we recognize that public policy cannot be tuned to an individual level. If you want to reduce speeding you do not 'look at the type of person prone to speeding,' you install speed bumps.

Comment: For those out there who don't know the distinctions among communities, and that seems to include this author, there is overlap, but clear distinctions. These are important to be aware of for public discussion. I've hosted a weekly ecstatic dance for 14 years, and only very recently heard the term 'ecstatic' applied to events that are basically rave/EDM (electronic dance music) dances. It is a trend in an attempt to find a more wholesome form of celebration than club, rave, or drug-prominent festival dancing. It's also fueled by disillusionment with the whole festival scene. So EDM DJ's have started re-fashioning their sets to sound more like ecstatic dance. Actual ecstatic/conscious/free form dance is barefoot, substance free (no alcohol served) and practiced in regular weekly events and workshops. 
We've had very little crossover with the Bliss jungle folk in the 15 years of my ecstatic dancing. But yes, they were 'hippie' cousins, pushing edges while we have focused on core health.

Comment: No surprise whatsoever here.  Schools chroncially fail to meet their basic obligations to students.  For example, parents are not supposed to pay for school supplies in the junior grades -- but must.  This is in addition to the "voluntary" levies -- and many schools shame the students of families who do not pay.   Any school that needs a playground needs to go the fundraising route; shocking when you realize that childhood obesity is a serious problem in this country.  

Affluent neighbourhoods can obviously afford to be more generous, and all parents want a good education for their children.  If the province fails in its obligations, of course they will step up.

The problem isn't so much underfunding as it is unrealistically high salaries for teachers and support staff.  If the bulk of the budget goes toward salary, there is that much less for education.

Comment: Take a longer term view and not just focus on flippers.   Tax for capital gains in stages over 10 years starting at three years.   Say, if you sell within three years, tax as income based on 100% inclusion.   Within 5 years - 75% inclusion.   Within 7 years - 50% inclusion.   Once you've owned for 9 years, there is no capital gains tax at all.  (The cut-off's can be adjusted, but keep the first one at least three years to discourage speculative flipping.

Make sure the data are captured and registered properly.   Allow for some kind of exemption for life-threatening illness and so on that requires an application.   Pain the neck and "nanny-statism" - I know.   However, we are where we are because action wasn't taken a long time ago. 

It also makes sense to consider foreign buyers, especially where they have no connection to Canada.   (e.g., are not citizens)   The big issue seems to be that nobody is capturing the data properly.   Capture good data and stop avoiding the issue.

Comment: There are farmer's markets that are essentially tourist destinations (fancy soaps, organic vegetables, etc) and they might be more expensive. But "real" farmers markets, with farmers selling their produce, tend to be cheaper than grocery stores. There is also more flexibility about portions - and of course the sellers are more amenable to selling you whatever amount you want.

This study, at least as described here, seems preposterous - like something from The Onion. There is a problem with the distribution of organic food because people without refrigerators have trouble storing it?

The bottom line is this: food is regulated, and food that is sold should be safe. That includes pesticides, GMO, etc. And in fact, I think our food is safe. I don't notice any taste or quality difference in "organic" food, and the anti-GMO movement is like the anti-vaccine movement: non-science.

We don't need to reduce the price of "organic" food. We just need to keep ensuring that all food is safe.

Comment: Not everyone needs home insurance. Not everyone needs renters insurance. Not everyone needs auto insurance. Not everyone needs liability insurance.

That's why it's different. That's why we should have basic coverage for all. Everyone pays in with their tax dollars, and everyone gets the benefit of basic coverage.

At that point, if you want more insurance? You're free to buy it.

You talk about freedom so much... what about the freedom to know that an accident or an unfortunate illness won't bankrupt you? That you can get the basic treatment and preventative services that every person needs? The kind of freedom that citizens of nearly every other country in the civilized world enjoys?

Comment: It would seem that the wife's income is much higher than the husband's. She should use her RRSP room to contribute the maximum to a spousal RRSP. She gets a higher tax reduction now, and later when the funds are withdrawn from a  RRIF,  it will be taxed in his hands. They will also have the advantage of splitting their RRIF and pension incomes to lower the overall tax bite. Furthermore, they can also use the husband's younger age to reduce the annual amounts which must be declared in the future when both of their RRIFs must be taken into income.

With a little effort they could trim their monthly expenses, particularly where vehicles are concerned, as several others have mentioned. I'd say that so long as their RRSPs are well invested in low fee accounts they should have little difficulty retiring any time after the wife reaches 65.

Comment: If you could not assume that anyone who disagrees with you does so just because they are ignorant, that would be swell. I understand how Supreme Court rulings work. They establish precedent. But that precedent has to be *applied* first by the Court in order for it to effect a change in law. The groundwork for a lawsuit to establish the ruling you and I would like to see the Court make has already been laid down, sure. But until someone actually brings a case dealing with this issue before the bench, and the court makes a ruling on this issue, specifically, the law hasn’t changed. And even when it is brought forth, I imagine that the Court will not be so broad in its application of the law as to prevent a social media platform from banning anyone at all. It will make exceptions, just as it always does.

Comment: When you get to Iceland, don't miss the Blue Lagoon. It was created originally as a a place to discharge water from a power plant heated with geothermal heat. The water is warm and rich in silica. The water is great for the skin too. It is about half way between the Keflavik International Airport and the capital, Reykjavik. It is like a public spa and inexpensive. Almost everyone in Iceland is bilingual and speak English. The people are very friendly. You will have a great time. You also get a huge tax break on any luxury or tourist purchases you make. You get the refund from the sales tax at the airport when you are about to depart Iceland.  Save your receipts. Stock up on Icelandic wool. Enjoy. BTW, if you have a medical emergency the healthcare is free, very civilized.

Comment: A Canadian corporation can be wholly owned by a non-resident. The director requirement you cite applies only to corporations set up under the CBCA. Each province has separate acts allowing the incorporation of companies.  Therefore you can have a Ontario Corporation, a New Brusnswick Corporation, etc.  The director requirements are different in each and you might want to look at New Brunswick's.
I believe you may have confused the concept of company and corporation and partnership. The only legal forms  other than direct ownership are corporations, partnerships and trusts. A "company" is a catch-all phrase but typically is used in reference to a "corporation" or to a "business". Holding a piece of residential real estate would not neessarily constitue a business in the conventional sense but would be sufficient for tax purposes. A primary test for partnerships is whether there is an activity being conducted with a view to profit. Two non-residents can form a partnership in Canada.

Comment: Schnurr is referring to estimates at current prices; the volume estimates show a smaller, but still substantial, drop in exports. The misnamed estimates in 2007 chained dollars show a 2.4% drop in merchandise exports as opposed to a 1.1% increase in merchandise imports. The Laspeyres volume measures show a 1.6% drop in merchandise exports as opposed to a 0.8% increase in merchandise imports. It should be noted that the growth in merchandise exports is still very strong if one looks at June as compared to May: it was 8.1% for the Laspeyres volume index at annualized rates, so our export growth may just be taking a one-month breather. Time will tell if this was just a one-month blip or if May 2017 growth (8.1% over 12 months) was as good as it gets for the Trudeau government.

Comment: In all sincerity, and if you haven't already, then perhaps you should engage with these communities or read up on the research related to helping them (the upsides of strategies that include harm reduction are well documented in many places and offer more insight than the kneejerk quips from others here who like to armchair quarterback this topic). Also, it's not JUST about getting them off drugs. It's also about reducing costs associated with this population: even simple care and monitoring can reduce both policing and health care costs.

I have volunteered in the DTES and it opened my eyes to many things. One essential thing that very few seem to grasp is that a huge proportion of people in that community have significant mental health issues that existed long before they had drug habits. Pretending this is just a story about "woe-is-me" hard-luck types or party people who choose to be addicts is just very lazy thinking.

Comment: I'm not exactly a defender, I'm more a person who wants to look at the facts. I think there are two main reasons Clinton used a personal server. The major reason, in my opinion, is that, because she has had 30 years of nonstop hostile investigation of her every word, on tape or on paper, she wanted to keep tight control over her correspondence, knowing that it would be presented, out of context, before the public and numerous hostile Congressional committees, and possibly, to a special prosecutor. The second reason is that it followed SecState precedent set by Rice and Powell, the latter of whom actually wrote to HRC recommending she use a private server (though Powell later denied this, the email exists). Powell also refused to hand over emails to a committee, and destroyed emails (that probably were personal business). The Democratic Committee didn't make a big issue of it, if you are in tune to contrasts.

So, I'm not perplexed. HRC's suspicion, if it is paranoia, is justified.

Comment: I can understand why some women dislike Trump and I admire anyone who has sufficient strength of conviction to attend protests such as this. I can also understand why Trump has become president and I do not believe it was on the strength of his appeal as a person. Rather, he was elected as an instrument of political change given a large portion of  US voters were fed-up with the complacency of both political establishments. Trump is not a dedicated liberal or conservative and he is very unpredictable. He is not beholden to any particular interest and certainly owes little to the Republican Party. No one, liberal,conservative or media pundit, can really forecast what he will do or how he will perform as President. There are no shortage of problems facing the country both internally and externally. They have been left festering for some time and are the driving force behind the desire for political change. Apprehension in these circumstances is understandable but the die has been cast.

Comment: "Vaccines have never been proven safe and effective in a Court of Law"

It is not, and never has been, the duty of a court of law to determine if a vaccine is either "safe" or "effective'.

Instead we have a separate legal entity that determines both the safety and efficacy of all medicine, and that separate legal entity *HAS* determined that vaccines are both safe and effective.

If this ever came up in court (and it probably has) it would be a dead-simple case to simply open up the file and confirm that YES, the vaccines are both safe and effective.

Comment: What is she thinking? She was against Brexit during the referendum. The referendum was not legally binding and even the lead Brexit champion Boris Johnson doesn't seem to think it's a good idea now. So why is she pushing ahead?

It does seem UKIP and other Brexit fans told Britons a few fibs during the referendum. And now Scotland, which voted to remain in the EU, may separate from the UK. And don't expect Northern Ireland to remain as they've gotten quite used to the open border with the republic. Indeed, Sinn Fein has just called for a separation referendum.

It seems to me that if Britons want out of the EU, they should have a government fully committed to that idea. So PM May ought to call a general election and run on staying in the EU-- with conditions. She'll win. And if Britons really, really want out, they'll vote Labour. But they're not likely to win.

That's the trouble with referendums. They just express an opinion of the moment without any guidance as to what to do next.

Anyhow, I 100% agree that people can't have it all and detached housing on, say, the West side of Vancouver will always be beyond the reach of the vast majority. But people certainly don't have to settle for these high policy-driven prices. Not a dozen years ago, a suburb like Burnaby was a viable community for local workers. Now, modest houses that could have been purchased on two good (not great) incomes are pushing $1M. The prices have effectively tripled or quadrupled.

When you unpack the policy reasons for this situation (massive expanded access to cheap debt for Canadians, facilitation of citizenship of convenience that leads to houses being treated like gold bricks by foreign money), it is frustrating. When you have the people benefiting from this mess lecturing you about a "free market" or the need to make sacrifices (like raising your family in a condo), you fight back.

 (When CNBC anchor Joe Kernen hosted Sen. Begich on his program, Squawk Box, on 6/17/13, he tried to make it easier on audiences.)
“I’m trying to put everyone in a box we can understand,” Kernen said. “Are you closer to a Pelosi Democrat or to a Rockefeller Republican?”

Comment: There is serious doubt now that we can both sustain government and sustain the PFD program over time. We are in this box because we have allowed our elected officials to "kick the can down the road",  We have entered "post oil Alaska" with a small population to tax. Also, we are now a relatively small oil producer therefore, the Permanent Fund now must become a source of revenue for state spending. This is not like the 80s when we had the oil production levels and only needed an increase in oil prices.  Now we don't have that level of production and with fracking technology we have slim hope of a significant oil price increase that won't be only temporary.  There may not be an immediate market for these incentivized recent oil discoveries.  Perhaps future incentives should be be paid  after the oil is sold,

Now I want to see concrete long term solutions that realistically appreciate our situation and that don't rely on hope because "hope" is not a viable plan of action.

Comment: I am sorry to have to point this out to you, but Doctors do in fact pay for CMPA. I certainly do. If a doctor gets sued, and Canadian doctors do get sued, it isn't the financial issues that are the worst problem for us, it is the emotional turmoil and extreme stress that this causes, regardless of merit of the lawsuit. It can destroy good people.  Employee sick time in a small business is a major problem. The patients need to be seen and are booked. The bills are still coming in.  Compared to an employee, doctors with staff have a significant extra burden. The time it takes to run the business( that you don't get paid for)  is also significant, that employees don't face. Doctors aren't typically great business people. They went to Medical School not business school. Many deal with life and death issues on a daily basis. I don't think many other professionals take that burden on. It seems to me they are taking on business risks and run a small business and should be treated accordingly

Comment: While you may have some legitimate points, your arguments would carry far more weight had you not sourced them from an advocacy organization. Physicians for Social Responsibility is an organization dedicated to fighting climate change, nuclear energy, and environmental toxins, which is somewhat ironic since the first goal could be solved via nuclear energy, the only non-hydrocarbon source of energy that makes economic sense.

Further, while I disagree with the alarmist view that climate change is an impending threat due to the rate at which it is occurring. Events that take place in seconds and minutes are impending threats. When thousands of square miles are inundated with seawater in a matter of seconds, it's called a tsunami. When that same inundation occurs over a geologic timescale, it's called sea level rise. People can adapt to and prepare for one and not the other.

That said, it absolutely blows me away how unprofessional and obnoxious AOGA's most public representative can be.

Comment: "The larger the mob, the harder the test. In small areas, before small electorates, a first-rate man occasionally fights his way through, carrying even the mob with him by force of his personality. But when the field is nationwide, and the fight must be waged chiefly at second and third hand, and the force of personality cannot so readily make itself felt, then all the odds are on the man who is, intrinsically, the most devious and mediocre — the man who can most easily adeptly disperse the notion that his mind is a virtual vacuum. 

 The Presidency tends, year by year, to go to such men. As democracy is perfected, the office represents, more and more closely, the inner soul of the people. We move toward a lofty ideal. On some great and glorious day the plain folks of the land will reach their heart's desire at last, and the White House will be adorned by a downright moron."

(For some reason I am not allowed to post the attribution source of this Mencken comment)

Comment: Not having a national pharmacare in Canada is a big joke on us that costs ordinary Canadians $$$ and is a relict of the political class's obsession with 'provincial rights', i.e. the demand by the provinces to control how health care is delivered in their jurisdiction.

In the absence of a national pharmacare scheme when you move from one province to another, for a job or to retire, there is a change-over period where your original province covers your drugs. Worse, drugs that may have been covered under the provincial drug program in your original province may not be covered in your new province. And the costs for the same drug will vary, as noted in Picard's article. 

Its time for this self-inflicted idiocy to end.

Comment: Grow up. 

The judge was wearing a poppy and, very briefly, a hat. Both are symbols -- both are, by some estimations, inflammatory and insensitive to the more delicate members of the community. In neither case should the delicate ones have the power to compel compliance with their demands.

Canadian judges long ago gave up the pretense of being entirely objective and neutral. Once the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Canada announces, extra-judicially, that the country is engaged in "cultural genocide," it's clear that political beliefs -- however wise or misguided -- are not grounds for sanctions. 

If the issue is a hat in court, then fine: it shouldn't be done. But the real issue, of course, is the message on the hat. A good number of people, it turns out, favour democracy only when the outcome pleases them. 

We were able to survive eight years of Obama -- we'll get through four years of Trump just fine, if the hysterics are able to get a grip on themselves.

Comment: Taken from a study entitled “Attendance at supervised injecting facilities and use of detoxification services. New England Journal of Medicine”

The study followed more than 1,000 Insite users between December 1, 2003 and March 1, 2005. Of this group, 185 (18%) began a detoxification program at some point during the study period. Individuals who used Insite at least weekly were 1.7 times more likely to enroll in a detox program than those who visited the centre less frequently. The study also found that contact with Insite’s addictions counsellor significantly increased a person’s chances of enrolling in detox. 
Contrary to fears that Insite might be deterring drug users from seeking treatment, these findings strongly suggest that Insite is facilitating entry into detoxification services among its clients.

Comment: "Celibate" and "unmarried" have been synonyms, so being unmarried (no matter how sexually active) IS being celibate. 

Chastity and celibacy are not the same, as an editor once cautioned me. I have been later told that "celibacy"--because of so much misuse of the term--can now mean concurrent unmarried AND chaste.

Alas, when I hear all this talk about divorced-and-remarried people having to  "live like brother and sister," I guess some folks in the Church think there should be millions of frustrated non-celibate folks who are also chaste.

I guess now the dictionary--and the Church--allows someone to be both non-celibate AND chaste?

Oh the confusion.

Comment: In the end the Republicans did the same thing. They locked up copies of the bill so other Republicans could not read it. Either way, though there is trutch ot the fact that medical care policies are difficult to predict and need to be tested and adjusted. This is what should happen with Obamacare-- make a few small changes and it will be fine-- two studies show this-- One by Standard and Poors, and one by the Kaiser Family Foundation-- both nonpartisan studies. Two thirds of americans do not want Obamacare repealed-- they want to see it improved.

Comment: Competition is fine.  But this isn't selling TVs or cell phones.  This is a party nomination where only one person advances to the real competition (the general election).  This is more like picking your starting QB BEFORE the real competition starts.

Last year's 5-way race (damn judges petition rulings) was a perfect example.  The highly diluted field allowed someone without broad appeal (Glenn) to take the nomination with just 37% of the vote.  The result in November was predictable.

They really need to switch to instant runoff voting where there's more than 2 candidates in the race.  Until they have that, then the party needs to practice the age-old method of weeding down the field internally before the primary.  That had already happened last year until a damn judge decided to ignore the ballot petition rules.

Comment: Okay.  Here is the deal.  There is something called manners.  Manners suggests that it is polite to keep one's nose out of other people's business unless you actually know that person.  And even in cases where you are family or a close friend, you should really not say anything about people's lives unless they are hurting themselves and others.  

With regard to remarried people and Communion, one should refrain from lecturing someone about receiving Communion or go to the priest and tattle about Jane or John Remarried.  If you want to express the opinion that divorce is bad, that is fine for you to do.  But MYOB when it comes to individual remarried people and their participation in the Church including their reception of the Sacraments.
